name: Short-horizon mean reversion (contrarian)
description: Signals that take the opposite side of very recent price moves (often intraday or close-to-close) expecting partial reversal over the next day(s). Includes delay-0 implementations designed to trade near the close (e.g., using vwap-close relationships).
semantic_text: Short-horizon mean reversion (contrarian) Liquidity provision and temporary price pressure/overreaction can revert quickly; late-day over/underperformance relative to VWAP may mean-revert. market microstructure

name: Short-horizon momentum (trend continuation)
description: Signals that follow the direction of recent moves (e.g., prior day intraday return open-to-close) expecting continuation into the next day (delay-1).
semantic_text: Short-horizon momentum (trend continuation) Information diffusion and order-flow persistence can create short-lived continuation in returns. market microstructure

name: Price–volume interaction / order-flow proxying
description: Alphas built from correlations/covariances/ranks of price changes and volume (or ADV-scaled volume), attempting to capture supply/demand imbalances, liquidity shocks, or informed trading proxies.
semantic_text: Price–volume interaction / order-flow proxying Volume and its relationship with price movement contains information about whether a move is supported by participation or likely to reverse. market microstructure

name: Relative-value to VWAP / intraday positioning
description: Signals based on deviations of close from VWAP, or of typical price measures from VWAP, often scaled/normalized and sometimes combined with range-based terms (high-low).
semantic_text: Relative-value to VWAP / intraday positioning VWAP is a common execution benchmark; deviations can proxy intraday buying/selling pressure and potential reversion around benchmark pricing. market microstructure

name: Cross-sectional normalization and industry neutralization
description: Use of cross-sectional ranks/scales and group demeaning via industry classifications (sector/industry/subindustry) to isolate idiosyncratic effects from common industry moves.
semantic_text: Cross-sectional normalization and industry neutralization Removing industry components reduces unwanted beta to sector/industry factors and focuses the signal on stock-specific microstructure effects. market microstructure

name: Volatility-linked alpha returns scaling
description: Across alphas, average returns scale with realized volatility approximately as return ~ volatility^p with p≈0.76; turnover does not explain returns once volatility is accounted for.
semantic_text: Volatility-linked alpha returns scaling Higher-risk (more volatile) alpha streams tend to deliver higher expected return, but not linearly; trading frequency (turnover) alone is not the driver. market microstructure

name: Turnover weakly explains alpha correlation structure
description: Pairwise alpha correlations are poorly explained by functions of turnover (e.g., linear/bilinear terms in log turnover).
semantic_text: Turnover weakly explains alpha correlation structure Two alphas can trade at similar speeds yet be structurally different (different underlying predictors), so turnover is not a reliable proxy for overlap/crowding in signal content. market microstructure

name: scale(x,a)

name: indneutralize(x,g)

name: Sharpe ratio (S_i)
